[b]edit:[/b] pause got patched in and the volume bug got fixed.

[b]tower words[/b] mixes tetris and word games, not unlike [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/dohi64/recommended/1782050]bloxi[/url] from 2021. what this one lacks in presentation and functionality, it makes it up by having actual word categories, so you're not just creating words randomly. there are [b]2 game modes[/b], [u]classic[/u] has [b]40 levels[/b], unlocked one by one, [u]endless[/u] is what the name suggests with an online leaderboard.

[b]blocks are all single letters and they fall really fast.[/b] arrows/asd to move them or make them fall even faster, but [b]placement is irrelevant[/b] and tiles fall from different columns, so there's often no real need for movement at all. [b]words are formed by clicking placed letters anywhere to match the current category.[/b] there are a bunch of [b]special blocks[/b], some explode, others slowly fade and have to be clicked to see what letter they hide, ice blocks can be used multiple times, etc.

besides the why-is-this-so-fast speed, a major issue on release was the game couldn't be paused, but esc to do so got patched in after a few days. until then you were either playing or could click the house icon to instantly abandon the game and go back to the menu. [b]mid-level progress isn't saved[/b]. levels are short, at least initially, but still. the next stage loads automatically and if you fail a level, it immediately starts again.

there's a 'keyboard enabled' toggle, which is essentially hard mode. if it's off (default state), both arrows and wasd work for movement, otherwise only arrows, as you obviously need letters to type words, though clicking still works. and if you press the wrong key, a bunch of random non-letter tiles appear. the other toggle is for 'automatic word detection', meaning you have to click the tick after making a word if it's off.

[b]presentation is very basic[/b], settings only include separate volume sliders besides the two toggles. [b]no windowed mode[/b] and alt+enter only makes a non-resizable window. the list of found words can be browsed in the menu.

as good as the concept is, the [b]execution is horrible[/b]. don't bother.

A "survival" game with a price that tells you exactly what you're getting into. 

This is neither a deep survival game, nor is it a game with any goals. You are simply dumped into this bizarre playground that makes no sense. Although there are tasks to fulfill, they are of the generic type found in other games. 

The moment you step out of your hut is like a monster Armageddon. There are gorillas, dinosaurs, massive scorpions, and many more creatures all over the place. They'll charge you once they see you, but they're friendly and will wait outside as you enter the hut. You can simply smack them, run back inside, and repeat until they’re dead. 

You have survival stats to worry about, like water and food, but it’s easier to just die and respawn with everything back to full. All your items will be gone, but that’s not an issue because of ridiculous item spawn rate. Various objects are constantly dropping. Swords, food, wizard hats, and blueprints for making new things will appear before your eyes in a matter of seconds.

It's not inviting to explore the map. There's nothing but desolate fields and mountains out there save for the primary spawn site and a few huts. There are also a few cavemen waiting outside, unconcerned about the creatures roaming the area. 

I can’t be mad at the game for knowing what it is: a silly joke that might be fun for half an hour.

[h1][u][b]Review of Project Speed 2.[/b][/u][/h1]
While Project Speed 2 (Kind of an odd name) does have Unreal Engine 5, it does not utilize it very well, as it has rather low texture qualities, even on the highest quality settings.
The audio design isn't great either, with rain droplets hitting the ground only using three pitches, and only one single sound.
The physics are rather wonky with cars going flying sometimes and the handling of cars being very... interesting, oversteering at around 30 kilometers an hour. 
Project Speed 2 centers itself around multiplayer, as stated in the showcase, however because almost nobody plays this game you're mostly limited to singleplayer, and since there's not much to do it leads to the game feeling very... empty.
Now I seem to have written a bit too much from what I usually do, so I'll just make a simple list down below...

I can't give it too much hate though, as it is still in rather early access, but I feel like there could have been a lot more to this game in the six months it has been out on Steam as of writing this review.

Liked:
Unreal Engine 5
Free
Achievement availability

Disliked:
Low texture quality even with high graphics settings
Bad sound design
Weird physics
Resetting just putting you in the same place you were, but flipped
Lack of players
Singleplayer being very empty
Car sounds being rather monotonous
The only other car is a DLC, costing 0.99 Euros, and is purely cosmetic
No first person view

Epilogue: I really tried to find things I liked about the game, trust me, but the bad things sadly outweigh the good things, but as I said, it's early access as of writing this, maybe in a year or when the game is officially released I might come back and give it another review. Who knows? It might become some Triple A game.

During my gameplay, the tutorial was a bit rough, but still taught you the core functions of the game and the dev was quick to correct and better the tutorial quickly. As for the server side of the game, it was so peaceful just drifting around in space. Your movement is very smooth and easy to navigate around, with a realistic feel. Harvesting resources was easy, and a lot of fun. The graphics of being in this space universe was just out of this world tbh. Highly recommend to anyone who love space style survival like games, but prepare for a slow start and some grinding a bit, that is until you upgrade your tools to better tier and begin gaining resources with a breeze. The dev and the discord community are very informative and usually pretty quick to respond. Its "FREE" at the time of this review, and recommend anyone interested in checking out this game as it has so much potential to be more :)

The game is pretty fun, especially if you play with 4 friends in full-team with no randoms. And the open beta looks good - it's very well optimised, not a single fps drop despite the enormous amount of dinosaurs, and the graphics are decent.
But it just not worth the price they sell it for, not even close, and the regional pricing of Capcom is pretty much non-existant.
Maybe I'll buy it on 75% (or so) discount in the future, if the game will still be alive which I honestly doubt because of poor pricing decision on it's release.

More of the same, just a couple hours of extra content. It's probably best played before you get into the endgame, otherwise you won't have much use for the ice blocks.

Would have been nice to have new flags or ship colours too.

boy, the DLC knife E is one of those where the game is trying to do a lot with a little, I would wait for sale, not to say it's bad, quite the contrary it's actually very good, and I had to take my hat set off numerous times and question what the hell I was looking at, seriously there are moments in this where I don't think I can put into words what I'm looking at, it's incredibly funny at times, it does push the envelope here and there again I'm not trying to spoil anything, although when it comes to performance in ran a little rough here and there, there was a lot of clipping with the guns or where my characters arms would just disappear or at the end of an event when a door was supposed to go up it did not open, the ending is psychopathic, if I could give this DLC and number when it comes to links I'd give it a two it's very short, it's a good short, but not for the amount of money they want, when it comes to story all give its a four, when it comes to the crazy insane stuff you're doing all give it a five, if you loved the base game you'll love this although I will warn people, the leading voice actor for the main weapon you used in the base game, is not in the DLC, because the voice actor for him has had allegations of sexual harassment labeled against him, nothing has been proven in court but you know these corporations, they would rather fire people or put people on leave then actually let the justice system do its job, that is what worries me about the future of the cQL if they're gonna bring back, Kenny in general I really loved the base game, because it did not push politics, but this game does it pushes hatred of capitalism and there is a character who is gay, and mentioned that he argued with his boyfriend and is gonna go back to him, look I don't hate people if their gay, but I wanna play a game that entertains me and the base game did that, this one kind of annoyed me with them pushing a couple things in the DLC, I know that the lead actor for the Witcher live action was accused of a lot of false accusations, because he did not push the progressive line, so apart of me wonders if that's what was happening, maybe the game developer  and this is just my opinion what might've happened, maybe because the original voice actor for Kenny, who is also a writer for the game maybe because he didn't push certain progress of notions in the writing department they created a lot of these false allegations in order to get him out of the game so they could start filling it with this stuff, either way I believe this DLC is a step back in the writing department, in certain areas it's a step forward but overall it's a step backward, just make games for gamers stop trying to push politics, because of this I'm gonna have to give knife a down vote, but don't misunderstand me it's a very sad down vote for me, if they didn't put the politics and game it would be a thumb up, but because of this I'm going to have to thumb it down.    Update Justin Roiland who was co owner of squash games has resigned as a member of that company it looks as though they're no longer going to use kenny's character obviously without him, the charges against Justin have been dropped, he is completely cleared of all charges, but as you know that's not going to be enough for some people, if he's not back for the second game and they've replaced his character with a girl, and the fact they're pushing more politics in their games, if it goes to that point then I'm going to have to walk away from high on life 2, seriously Justin is the blood and soul of this game company, when people can make false allegations against you and destroy your life, I know how that feels, I've lost jobs because people made false allegations, so have you guys you need to rehire him and stop this nonsense, seriously I know the signs of a dying company and this is one of those signs.  If you're willing to throw away a founding member of your company who is literally the main voice actor for your game and a really damn good writer, then maybe you don't deserve to have a company.  Time will tell.

The expansion is really lackluster. No new arts, enemies or a big variety of bosses (just the final boss). It's like The Taken King expansion where they recolored existing enemies and gave them a glowing aura. Only "expansion worthy" content here is the story which is alright but not as good as the first half of the base game in my opinion, DLC doesn't have any massive implications or impact on the overall plot of Arise. A bit odd considering they took so long to release this especially after making a statement of not continuing Arise's story, so I thought they had to be cooking if they went back on their word. Overall, good to see the characters again but, just like the SAO DLC, way too overpriced, wait for a big sale.

Well, I can safely say that this style of game is not my jam. Jank for the sake of it is still jank. I am trying to be nice to this because I don't necessarily feel like I am the target market. The visuals are not bad, but the frame rate suffers A LOT. The audio could use some work. The controls are terrible: sometimes you jump and the guy just jumps in place despite pressing forward. It is difficult to judge the direction of a jump. The character glitches through terrain and doesn't always grab on to anything. Having looked at the reviews for Only Up, this seems like it has the same issues as that minus all the NFT promotion. In the absence of knowledge, I have gone with a thumbs up (because there is no thumbs sideways.) If you like this type of game, this is more of that type of game.
